episode.title: Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers v. Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe Railroad Company

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument next in Number 94-1592, Brother... spectators are admonished to be quiet until you get outside the courtroom.
The Court is still in session.
We're going to hear argument next in Number 94-1592, Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers v. The Atchison, Topeka, and the Santa Fe.
Mr. Mann, you may proceed whenever you're ready.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
The obvious question for you to ask me this morning is, if Congress intended for waiting time for deadhead transportation to be time on duty, why didn't it say so specifically?
Well, the answer to that, at least in my mind, is very simple.
We're dealing with a statute that first of all encompasses many train operations.
Even the petitioners acknowledge that there are thousands of train operations daily.
At the time of the '69 statute, there were 36,000 train operations each day, so--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What do you mean when you say train operations?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Meaning, a crew goes on duty and performs service for the railroad.
That would be one train operation, Your Honor.

And the other answer to that is, and I think it's the real guts of the case is, there was no need to specifically state that waiting time was time on duty because Congress treated that issue in several sections of the statute, and I refer the Court to section 21103(b), and I will talk about (1), (2), (3), (4), (5), and (6) subsections.

And in each one of those subsections it's very clear that Congress was attempting... and I submit to you they did close the loopholes, and one basic problem is that railroad workers at that period of time were sitting on trains for hours on end waiting for a pickup crew or another train to come along and take them to their final release period, and it's... throughout the entire amendments the sole purpose was to close those loopholes, and they did it in several ways.
First of all, you don't have to be working at all to be covered as time on duty under the act, because it's very clear... you know, I'm just a country boy, Your Honors, but English is English.
It says, interim periods available for rest at a place--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Where are you reading from, Mr. Mann?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Excuse me, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And where will we find it?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: This is section 21103--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Page 2 of the petition?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --In my brief, Your Honor, it is... yes, page 2 of the petition.
Page 3, number (5), subsection (5), Your Honor, an interim period available for rest.
Now, what the carriers and the Government is telling you is that this period of time should not be considered here.
They want to write out and put conditions on each section, not giving it its broad and plain meaning.
They--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, are you reading out the word, interim?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --The interim, Justice Souter, means interim between the time you go on duty and the time that you're finally released from duty.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: It doesn't mean interim as between two periods of active duty?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: It does not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Do we have a definition in the statute?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Well, we have some legislative history.
In the hearings, as well as in the Senate report, it talks about final release of all... finally released from all responsibilities.
The proof of the pudding there is--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I'm sorry, I'm just not getting it.
I'm sure somewhere they use that phrase, but how are you connecting that with the meaning of the word?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Well, interim--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Interim.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Interim means, as discussed in the House hearings and the industry spokesman, the Association of American Railroads, made that point clear, Your Honor, if I--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, he may have done it, but is there a House or a Senate report that defines the term, or indicates--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --It does not define the term.
Congress--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --If I understand your argument correctly, your meaning would have been conveyed better if the word interim were left out, just a period available for rest.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Well--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: What does interim add that helps rather than hurts your position?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --It... I submit it doesn't hurt my position.
It includes periods for operations.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But you would be stronger, your argument would be stronger, would it not, if the statute didn't say, interim?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Somewhat, but I don't think it's definitive, because as the railroad... the chief railroad witness, and I think it's very critical, testified, and I refer to the House hearings at page 135, where Mr. Manion... Mr. Manion was the vice president of the Association of American Railroads, and he was talking about the problems of deadheading transportation and what would happen if the bill as was introduced were adopted, and after he discussed that part, he said, however, under another provision of H.R. 8449, which is the section dealing with interim periods for rest, section 1(b)(3)... now, that is exactly the same as what was passed, subsection (5), and I quote:
Periods available for rest at other than a designated terminal will be included as time on duty.

Consequently, if a crew reaches the hours-of-service limit in the country and is relieved there, it will still be on duty for purposes of hours-of-service purposes because it is not relieved at a designated terminal.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Who says this?
Well, Mr. Mann, even for people devoted to legislative history, that's a fairly low level, isn't it, what a witness testified?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Except, Your Honors, this was an industry spokesman, the Association of American Railroads, on a bill that only affected them, and what Congress was attempting to do is to close all these loopholes, and I submit to you, this statement as far as I am concerned--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, how do we know that Congress intended to "close all these loopholes"?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Well, the act solely--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: It's not called the loopholes-closing act.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --No, Your Honor.

The act solely deals with placing in the act periods of time that not... that previously were not time on duty as being time on duty, with one exception, deadhead transportation to the final release point.
Everything else that they did, the Congress made it time on duty to eliminate every abuse that was testified to in these hearings, and this is the industry spokesman.
Now, you can look at the hearings, and I spent some time doing that, to see what all the rest of the witnesses stated from the industry.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But is there something in there that talks about the definition of deadhead transportation?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Yes, there is.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Deadhead transportation, I would think sometimes when people are transported they include the time that they're sitting around in the station waiting room--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Well, that's--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --or the airport--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --That's one of the issues.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --and sometimes they don't, so it all seems quite ambiguous to me, anyway, and if it's ambiguous, shouldn't you leave this kind of interpretation to the agency?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Well, two things, Justice Breyer.
One is, of course, the industry, how they dealt with deadhead transportation, and here's how they define it... Mr. Manion again.
Deadheading may be defined as travel performed by railroad employees at the direction of a railroad.
Now, he was not the only railroad witness.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: But that doesn't do it, does it?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: I say I'm traveling to Boston.
I might or might not include in my travel time the time spent at the airport.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --That's correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.
So is there something there that says, by the way, we don't mean time spent at the station, or spent at the airport, or sitting around waiting for the train to show up?
Is there anything like that?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: There are three things.
One is commingled service, which is defined in the statute as any other service for the carrier.
You are part of the crew.

You're not free to leave the premises except being under the control and subject to being called, and you're not finally released from duty until you get back at the terminal and do other ministerial duties.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Mr. Mann, is it your position that if you are deadheaded back to your final point of release, while you're waiting to get the first train, let's say to Omaha, that is on-duty time?
What about... suppose you have to wait again in Omaha to get another train to New York City, where you're going to be released?
What about that wait?
Is that part of deadhead--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: All time... all time--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --So you're not on duty while you go from Omaha to... where did... from wherever you're... wherever you end your work to Omaha, you're not on duty--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --You are on duty.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --While you're being transported?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: You're on duty.
That's specifically in the statute.
From the time you mark on duty, and that's subsection (4) of the--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I thought deadheaded transportation back is not counted.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Deadheaded transportation back, at the end of your tour of duty, at the end of your tour--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Okay--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --of operations--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --My tour has ended in San Francisco.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Okay.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And I... they've arranged to get me back by putting me on a train to Omaha, all right.
Now, you say while I'm waiting in San Francisco, I'm still on duty, all right.
What about while I'm waiting in Omaha?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: It's all commingled service, and it's also time that is free for rest, and under the statute, that's on-duty time.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And what about the transportation while I'm on the train between San Francisco and Omaha?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: That is not, because of the statutory provision.
That's why Congress carved out this one exception.
The only exception is that it will not be counted as time on duty, nor time off duty.
That one period of actual movement, traveling in... traveling in is the key.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why is that magic?
I don't understand that.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Well, because--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, if... it makes no sense at all.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Well, maybe... maybe free at rest makes no sense at all, either, but it would create an anomaly.
The anomaly would be this--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You don't think it's an anomaly that I'm on duty while I'm at rest and back on duty whenever I start moving again?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Congress said so.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And if I have eight stops along the way, I'm on-off, on-off.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: If Congress had not said that rest time was time on duty, I would agree with you, but Congress didn't say that.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Mr. Mann, what happens if I'm being transported back in a van and there's a breakdown, and it takes 3 hours to get that van fixed so it can move again to the place where I'll be released?
We know that the time that you're in the van is deadhead time, and it's not on-duty time.
What about when the car breaks down and I'm waiting to have it fixed?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: It's a good question, but I would submit to you that the way Congress envisioned this, I would argue to you that any time that you're not traveling, and it's very clear if you look at the statute and the meaning of the terms, if you're not traveling in the deadhead transportation, then it's either commingled service, you're performing other service--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: No service.
I'm waiting--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --When you're waiting--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --for the van to be fixed.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --that's rest time.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, why isn't it on duty time, as it is in Justice Scalia's Omaha wait.
Why is he on duty in Omaha but not on duty sitting on the side of the road?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Congress said that an interim period available for rest is time on duty.
You can be at rest completely--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: He's at rest on the side of the road.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Mm-hmm.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So he's on duty, so the answer to Justice Ginsburg's question is, he's on duty.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: He doesn't have to be performing any duty.
He can simply be doing nothing, just sitting there waiting, doing absolutely nothing--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But it's treated as on-duty time.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Specifically.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yes.
I assume you don't take the position that when the van stops for a red light he's back on duty, do you?
[Laughter]
Is it a... it's not an in-motion theory, not completely that, huh?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Typically, the problem... we wouldn't be here if there hasn't been tremendous abuses.
What we have as a typical situation, at the end of the 12 hours a crew is waiting and waiting and waiting.
We have evidence in the record that up to 10 hours, sometimes, they have to wait for someone to come and get them--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Can I go back... I'm... I--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --My question... and you just didn't have a chance to get out the other two things--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Oh--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --and what I was curious, remember, that this word deadhead transportation struck me, at least in the statute, as ambiguous, that of course deadhead transportation is limbo time, yes--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --but what is deadhead transportation, and my question was, what evidence is there that you could not... not that you... but you could not read those words, deadhead transportation, to include time in the station, time waiting to go on the train itself, as we do with airplanes and trains normally.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: If you're--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: And what is it in... and you listed three things.
The first thing was, you said I should look at the commingled, the definition of commingled--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Commingling--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --and you were going to mention two others.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --That's correct.
One is the rest period, interim period for rest--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Where would I... where do I find--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --That is--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --You mean just in the statute here, or in--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --In the statute.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: --All right.
I've looked at that.
It didn't seem--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Oh... oh, I--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --to me that it was clear.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Well, let me--

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: One is the definition of commingled in the statute, the other is the definition of rest period, and what was the third?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --The third is, what was Congress trying to do here?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Okay, what?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Congress was trying to eliminate the abuses, and this was one of the greatest abuses that the industry was accomplishing.
They were leaving these crews out there an inordinate amount of time, and they're still doing it today.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Well, if, in fact, it is an abuse, and if, in fact, the agency has significant delegated power to define deadhead transportation either way or partial ways, then couldn't you deal with that problem through the agency dealing with it?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: I don't think the agency, Justice Breyer, has the authority here.
This is the one statute, the only safety statute on the books, in which the Federal Railroad Administration does not have regulatory authority.
They enforce, but they have no regulatory authority.
In fact, Congress took away the authority.
In the old statute in 1908, the old statute, the Interstate Commerce Commission did have that jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But they can interpret.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: They can interpret, yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: They can interpret, and they did.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: They did.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And they said, we think that two things go together.
When you're going to the job, then the waiting time, everything, is on-duty time.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: And when you're going from the job, then everything is this limbo thing.
Why doesn't that just make entire sense as an interpretation?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: It does in one respect, but the other respect I can just say, the very opposite is true.

Going to deadhead trans... deadhead to-duty assignment obviously includes the time you report to duty, and the time you are actually traveling, because the first subsection states very clearly that time on duty begins when you report for duty, so obviously, and I could argue that if that is time on duty from the point of reporting to duty and actually moving in transit, then the opposite situation coming back is the same.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But one thing is not the same.
You can't get very far with your release point, because the statute tells us that the deadhead transportation time back, before the point at which you're released, that that time is limbo time.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: That's correct, but the statute also tells you that, unlike what the respondents are saying, it tells you that you are not... there's... the position of the respondents, simply put, is that the employee is off-duty, no further obligations, after the 12 hours is reached.
That's just not the fact.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, that's a factual question.
We didn't take this case to figure out the fact of whether there are duties, and I at least am going to decide it on the assumption that there aren't.
Now, if you can prove that there are duties in a particular case, it's a different case.
But let's assume there are no duties, that the railroad worker is simply waiting to go back to where his rest time begins.

Now, I can see why Congress would want deadhead time, including the time waiting for the deadhead transportation to arrive, I can understand why they would want that to count at the beginning of the work period, because by the end of the work period, the worker's going to be very tired.
You should count that time against him, right?
But at the end of the work period, what difference does it make?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: He's not doing any more work for the railroad, his rest time for the mandatory period of rest he has to take doesn't begin... this is limbo time, right, it's not rest time.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So what... why would Congress want it to count towards work time?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: There are several--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I can't understand it.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --answers to that.
Number 1, why would they want just rest time to be time on duty?
Because there were abuses at that time, and there are still abuses.
That's one reason.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes, but that's going back to your claim that in fact they're really being required to do something.
It seems to me that that answer is inconsistent with the--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: They're not required... Justice Souter, they're not required to do anything, and they're off... I mean, and they're on duty, specifically by the statute, and that was what the industry spokesmen were telling Congress at the time.
Congress, if you adopt this, we can never let anyone off at an interim point.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Yes, but--
--When they have more duties later.
That was addressing--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: They do.
They still do.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --the situation when they have more duties later, so that their total on the job, their total time on the job will be stretched, and by the end of the job, they'll be very tired.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Justice Scalia--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Here we're talking, by definition, about a situation where their job is done, and it's not going to be counted toward their rest time, and it's not going to make them more tired for any duties that they perform.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --I respectfully differ with you because, as I've pointed out in my reply brief, the duties don't end.
When you get at the end--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: You're going to win in front of the Seventh Circuit.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Sir.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: If that's true, then under the Seventh Circuit's opinion, you're going to win, ultimately.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: The Seventh Circuit did not consider anything but that one section of subsection (4), time spent in deadhead transportation.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: They did not look--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: If you can go back to the Seventh Circuit, or the district court under the Seventh Circuit opinion and say, aha, they have responsibilities, then you're going to win.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Well, I can only suggest--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I mean, the whole point of our taking this case is not to decide whether you win or not--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Correct.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --on that hypothesis.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Correct, but I think it is significant in that it counters the argument of the respondents that all duties end at that 12-hours time, and it doesn't.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But your case... in answer to my question, you were candid, and I appreciated it.
You said if the van breaks down so that they're not moving, that's limbo time, and it's clear that in that situation they have no trains to watch--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --no safety hazards to report, they have nothing to do--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: --except wait.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: And they are not free to go.
They are part of the crew, still, until they finally mark off at the away-from-home terminal.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask you a question about the 1969 hearings, and you quoted Mr. Manion's statement, which I guess is the same one, at page 20 of your brief.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And his references to 1(b)(3)(A) in the bill that was then pending, that's what finally was enacted as subsection (5), is that correct?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And am I correct in understanding that at that time the subsection (4) with the second clause in, at least, was not in the bill?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: The deadhead transportation?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yes.
That was not yet in the bill, is that correct?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Not in the... not as it was finally passed.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And so it is fair to infer as part of your argument, I gather, that in paragraph (4) everything after the word, but, was enacted in response to the concern expressed by Mr. Manion on page 20 of your brief.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: It was... well, deadhead transportation in the originally drafted bill stated that all of the deadhead time was time on duty, so he was referring to both provisions, except when I read to you on page 135 of the House hearings, that only related to the subsection (5).

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Which was then subsection (3).

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And (4) was amended in response to this testimony, is your position.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And my question is, if you... and the question, then, is, what does the word deadhead transportation mean in that amendment, under your analysis?
The question, does it include the time waiting for the transportation to begin?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: And let me address--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Let me finish my question, please.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Oh, I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And so that's what we're trying to decide, as I understand it.
Now, if your view is correct that it does not include the period before they get on the bus, or whatever it is, how did that solve the problem he described on page 20 of the brief?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: It didn't solve that problem.
They are still--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Unless you construe it the way the Government does.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --They're still on duty.

Now, I want to point out, Justice Stevens, that another industry spokesman, a Mr. Hilt, who was the chairman of the National Railway Conference... this is the negotiating arm for the railroad industry.
He was asked, what does deadhead mean?
He said, on page 220 of the House hearing, deadheading is being transported from one point to another at carrier's orders without performing any service, and then, later in his testimony--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But again, he's describing something before that's in the bill.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Yes, but later he was asked by Congressman Tiernan, in regards to defining deadhead, would you say to the committee that the definition covers the complete description of deadheading, and his answer was... he didn't fully answer.
He said, deadheading is a widely used term, except management relationships is more or less the complete definition, and then Congressman Tiernan again pressed him.
He said, you don't want to add anything to the definition you gave with regards to what deadheading is, and he said, I don't think so.
So he is saying to Congress, it is only transportation in, and that's all it is, the transportation.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Maybe he was wrong.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: But that's what Congress relied on.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: No, but you still haven't answered--
--You think... how do you know that?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You really think--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --I really think--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --Who do you think heard that testimony?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Who did?

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Do you think Congress heard that testimony?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Well, it was their hearings.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: How many people do you think were present there?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: There were 30-some on that committee.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Okay, so you think because 30 Members of Congress, if they were all present at the hearing, heard him say those words.
You want us to assume that therefore the statute means what he said.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: It's what Congress--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Does that seem reasonable to you?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --I do, because this committee is the one that drafted the provisions, and they relied on what the witnesses told them, and it was part of that testimony--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They didn't pass the statute.
There are how many, 432 Members of Congress, 530, 532, something like that.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They passed the statute, not the 30--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: They passed it based on the representations of the chairman of the committee.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --They did.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Unanimously, I might add.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But counsel, even if you confine yourself to the committee members... I understand what you're trying to say.
You're not going to convince Justice Scalia on this, but you might convince me, so give it a try.
[Laughter]

How does the amendment... what I don't understand under your view, assume that all the committee members meant the amendment to solve the problem described there, as I read it, it does not solve the problem--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: It only--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: --because the time between they get off the crew and they wait for the bus could run out to several hours and still cause the very violation he's concerned about.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --That's correct.
Congress didn't buy that.
That's the whole point I'm making.
The only thing they bought from the railroad industry was, we're going to give you a break on deadheading--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I see--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --not time on duty.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --Why would they buy that little piece of the problem?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Because--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Why would they say, we're going to fix this part but you're in trouble for the rest?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --Because it's the abuses, Justice Souter.

They had crews sitting out there hours on end, and they still do, and the problem is, maybe there's no immediate danger to safety because they're not... the crew's not going to operate this particular train any more, but it gets cumulative.
Day-in, day-out, you're not knowing when you're going on duty, 8 hours later today, 6 hours earlier tomorrow, and it cumulates, and as I quoted--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: They have guaranteed rest period whenever they get back, and that is not shortened whether this limbo time... I mean, this limbo time doesn't go toward that.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --It doesn't, but you have... and I submit that cumulative fatigue is a cause of serious safety problems, as stated by the National Transportation Safety Board, which I've quoted, as stated by the General Accounting Office as well--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Do they get paid for the limbo time?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --They do.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So why do they mind?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: It's a safety problem.
We're not talking about wages.
We're talking about safety.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: They still have to have the off duty.
They have to have the off-duty hours after the limbo time plus the transportation is over.
They have to have the 10 off-duty hours anyway.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So why does it become... I mean--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: It's not an economic problem.
That's the whole point.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: --No, no, but I mean, why is it a safety problem if when they get back they still have to have the 10 hours?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Because day in and day out, that time is not regular, and it cumulates this fatigue, and I... when you have an opportunity to look at the... and even the reports of the Federal Railroad Administration point out to the... this problem in the railroad industry, and it is definitely a cause of accidents.

Employee error causes about 30 percent of the rail accidents in this country, and a significant portion of those that were addressed by the National Transportation Safety Board involve fatigue, and both chairman of the board, as well as the vice chairman, going to Congress several times trying to get attention to this problem, and this is what Congress was trying to do, and that's why they didn't buy the amendment sought by the railroads.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I guess the only difficulty I have with your response is, I mean, you're relying on legislative history for part of the answer, but when we get to drawing the distinction between the waiting time and the transportation time, and you're saying well, Congress bought that distinction, there's nothing in the legislative history which you were previously relying on that supports you.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: They didn't change the bill.
The bill is exactly the same as what was complained of.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: But it seems... it just strikes me as odd that when they adopted, in effect, the compromise which are the... when they adopted the language following but, in what is now (4), it just strikes me as odd, if we're going to rely on legislative history, to find that there is no explanation of what you're telling us.

Why might they not have said, well, we're going to add these words following but, and we're going to put them in (4), but that does not affect the question of how we're going to treat waiting time, because waiting time is subject to abuse.
There's nothing in the legislative history record that addresses this.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Maybe not specific words, waiting time, but they addressed it clearly in two ways.
One is, which I've just mentioned, they did not change the wording at all from the introduced bill and that which was complained about by the industry.
They didn't change it at all.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But they added that part of subsection (4).
Yes.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That's a change in response to... arguably is a change in response to the concern you've identified.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Not on waiting time.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, you think it isn't because it doesn't expressly say that.
It's a question of, what did they mean by deadhead transportation?

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: That's what--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Did they intend to include waiting time, which would have solved the problem--

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --But that's--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --if you read it that way.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: --They solved it by saying you can't get that relief that you want.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Mann.

turn.speaker: lawrence_m_mann
turn.label: Mr. Lawrence M. Mann
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Your time has expired.
Mr. Stewart, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:
In the view of the Federal respondents, time spent waiting for the arrival of a deadhead vehicle at the conclusion of an employee's duty assignment is neither on nor off-duty time.
That construction is consistent with the text of the pertinent statutory provision, and with the policies underlying the Hours of Service Act.
As Justice Breyer was saying in one of his questions, if a person is asked, how much time did it take you to travel from Washington and Boston, the question is ambiguous.
If the import of the question is, how big a chunk out of your day did the process of travel take, a person would normally answer it in a way that included associated waiting time.

If the person were known to find air travel particularly uncomfortable or unpleasant, the person might naturally infer that the point of the question was, how much time were you placed in this uncomfortable position, and might answer it in a way that included only the time actually in the air.

So to see whether waiting time should be counted as part of time spent in deadhead transportation, I think the inquiry should focus on, why did Congress define this as limbo time in the first place, and do the same concerns that caused Congress to define a category of limbo time apply with equal force to the waiting time at issue here, and for all purposes relevant to the Hours of Service Act, the time spent waiting for the deadhead vehicle is functionally indistinguishable from time actually riding in that vehicle.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, what about the abuse argument?
There's no... the railroads weren't engaging in abuses while they were transporting.
They were engaging in abuses by being very unsystematic and uncaring about getting the... doing the transportation.
I think that's his argument.
What is your response to that?

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: Well, a couple of responses.

I think first, as to what complaints of abuse were brought before the congressional committee that held the hearings, the union's complaints focused both on the waiting time and on the length of transportation itself.
That is, there were statements to the effect that--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: They didn't draw any distinction, you're saying.

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: --No, and--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: So that the problem Congress had was a unified problem.

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: --That's correct, and the Senate committee report stated that part of the problem was that an employee... several hours of an employee's off-duty time might be time deadheading back from his duty assignment, so clearly... there's no evidence in the legislative history that Congress believed that the ride in the deadhead vehicle itself was typically short, but that the waiting periods were typically lengthy, so I don't believe that the legislative history provides a basis for distinguishing between the two.
The reason that time spent in deadhead transportation is limbo time is that it shares some of the characteristics of both on and off-duty time.
That is, the employee is not free to come and go as he pleases.

The employee is unlikely to have a meaningful opportunity for rest, and therefore it would be inappropriate to count this as off-duty time and count it towards the minimum number of consecutive hours of rest that he has to--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I just get your view on one, kind of fundamental thing for me?
Is it... do you agree that the second clause in subparagraph (4) was inserted in response to the concern expressed by the testimony of Mr. Manion?

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: --I don't know if I would say that Mr. Manion specifically, but yes, I think--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Just generally.

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: --Yes.

The original bill, the bill as originally introduced provided that time deadheading either to or from a duty assignment would be considered on-duty time, and this appears to reflect a... to define the deadheading from a duty assignment as limbo time appears to reflect a compromise that allayed the concerns of the railroads while ensuring that this would not be treated as off-duty time, thereby depriving the employee of an adequate opportunity for rest.
So because the employee is not free to come and go as he pleases, and is unlikely to have a meaningful opportunity for rest, it would be inappropriate to consider this off-duty time.

On the other hand, so long as the employee has no duties to perform, his fatigue can pose no danger to himself and others, or others, and therefore it would be inappropriate to treat this as on-duty time, and I think it's instructive to contrast this with the interim periods available for rest that Mr. Mann referred to.
That is, the reason that the interim periods are defined as on-duty time is not that the employee poses a danger during those periods himself.
That clearly wouldn't be the case if the employee is performing no services.

Rather, the reason is that if these periods are not provided at a place where an employee actually has an adequate opportunity for rest, the employee is likely to be tireder at the end of that period than at the beginning, and therefore they need to be counted as on-duty time in order to ensure that he's not performing safety-sensitive tasks more than 12 hours after he initially reported for duty.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Do you know how many designated terminals an employee usually has?

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: Well, typically, I think my understanding is that typically there would be a home terminal and an away-from-home terminal.

This is generally a subject of collective bargaining, and Mr. Johnson may have a more precise answer than I do, so that what is a designated terminal insofar as a particular employee is concerned is defined not by the act, but by the collective bargaining agreement.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But under your view, if the employee waits for deadhead transportation after his duty, when he's off duty, and then goes to a designated terminal which is available for rest under (5), but then he's also waiting for further transportation, I take it that this is on duty, because he has a place to rest, even though he's also waiting for further deadhead transportation.

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: I'm not sure if I understand the question, but our position is that after the employee has been released of the obligation to perform any duties, all of the waiting and the actual riding would be considered limbo time, and the statute speaks of--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: No, but it's on-duty time once he gets to a place other than a designated terminal and it's available for rest, pursuant to (5), or is that not an interim period?

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: --That's not an interim period.

The interim periods would be those that are preceded and followed by periods of service, and again, the reason for treating those periods differently is, if you're going to have to perform services when the period is over, we're concerned about whether you're going to be tired and pose a safety hazard at that time, but if your tour of duty is up, if you're simply in the process of getting from your duty assignment to the place that you'll get your 8 or 10 hours consecutive rest, that concern is not present.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: I see.
So interim is followed and preceded by on duty.

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Stewart, does the Government assert any entitlement to deference of its views in this case?

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: Yes, we do.

This is... obviously, this litigation has taken a strange path in the sense that the Government is asserting a different reading of the statute than we asserted in the court of appeals, but the concerns that caused the FRA to shift its position, briefly, essentially are inapposite once the case comes before the Court.

That is, in the Seventh Circuit the Government was asserting that the interest in Nation-wide uniformity was so great as to outweigh the interest in choosing the better of the two readings as between two that the FRA considered within the realm of reasonableness.

Given that we're in this Court, and that whatever ruling this Court hands down obviously will have Nation-wide application, there's no need to balance any concern for uniformity against competing interests.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What that would mean, of course, if we agree with you on the deference point, is that although we... if we were to find your interpretation reasonable, you could change the interpretation later.
Even if we thought yours was the more reasonable you would still be able to go to the other one.

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: I think that's correct.
It would depend to a certain degree on how the Court wrote the opinion.
if the Court went out of its way to say not only is this a reasonable construction but it's in our view the only one that could plausibly be asserted--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Now, the FRA does not have rule-making authority explicitly conferred, does it?

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: --No, that's correct, as to the Hours of Service Act.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And there is a circuit conflict, is there not, on whether agencies that do not have rule-making authority are entitled to deference?

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: I think there is... there are... this Court has accorded--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: We've reserved the question, haven't we?

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: --Right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You don't want us to decide that in this case, do you?

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: I think because our... clearly, we believe our reading of the statute is the better of the two, and if the Court--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I think... do I understand you right to be saying that you're not talking about the Chevron kind of deference, because there's no delegated rule-making authority here, right?

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: --That's correct.
The FRA is entrusted with the responsibility for assessing civil penalties, but it is not given substantive rule-making authority.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: So you're talking about the Skidmore kind of deference where the agency, because it's been in the business, where the Court would look to the persuasiveness of its reasons that's kind of a--
--Is that what you were talking about?
I was talking about Chevron deference.
I would have to rephrase my question.

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: I under--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You understood me to mean Chevron deference, didn't you?

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: --Yes, I did.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Let me just throw this into the discussion.
Which opinion, Judge Bauer's or Judge Easterbrook's, do you think better explains your position on deference?

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: Well, part of the problem with that is that in the--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: If you have an answer.

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: --I don't have an answer, because I think neither really goes to the question.

That is, at this point, in the court of appeals the question of deference arose in the context of the FRA's argument that it's concern for Nation-wide uniformity was so great as to trump its view as to what was the better reading of the statute, and we... the FRA in the court of appeals asked that court to defer to the FRA's view regarding the importance of Nation-wide uniformity as opposed to the importance of getting the better of the two answers, so the two opinions were addressed to that sort of deference.

Here, what we're talking about is deference regarding the FRA's view as to what is the more persuasive meaning of the statutory language, so the types of things that Judge Bauer and Judge Easterbrook were debating really are not particularly germane to this Court's resolution of the question.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: They're like ships passing in the night, I guess.

Mr. Stewart is there anything in the record that indicates why the Government didn't appeal the Ninth Circuit and try to reconcile its views of the better interpretation with national uniformity that way?

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: There is nothing in the record.
I think--

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I don't wish to go outside it.
I just wondered whether there was anything in it.

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: --I would only remark that it was the first court of appeals ruling that had addressed the question, and it would be... there would be nothing in this Court's rules, obviously, that would preclude us from filing a cert petition or the Court from granting it, but it would not be consistent with the Court's normal practice.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Well, why didn't you then... I mean, if you still persisted, I mean, why isn't the answer, that is, if you still persisted in thinking the other view the better one, why wouldn't it have been worth the Government's while at least to persist in one other circuit to get a conflict and get the thing up here?

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: Again, these go to questions of both litigation strategy and also the FRA's view as to the importance of uniformity as of a particular moment.
Certainly a reasonable person could believe that that would have been the better course.
Obviously, the reasonableness of that decision is not before the Court at this stage.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: You do agree that, if there's any duty assigned, like watch the train to see that there's no vandalism, that that's full on-duty time.

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: That's correct.
With respect to the vandalism point, I would like to distinguish between two types of instructions that an employee could be given.
If the employee were told, watch for vandalism, be alert, be vigilant, that is clearly on-duty time.

If the employee were told, you can do whatever you want, read, play cards, sleep, but if you happen to see vandalism you have an obligation to report it, we wouldn't regard the reading, sleeping, et cetera time as on-duty time, but if vandalism happened to catch the employee's eye, and he reported it pursuant to instructions, that act would be on duty.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: He could be given those instructions for rest time, too, I assume.

turn.speaker: malcolm_l_stewart
turn.label: Mr. Malcolm L. Stewart
turn.text: That's correct, and even if there were no identified contingency that would call the employee back into duty, these people are always in radio contact with supervisors.

The possibility would always exist that a supervisor would give an instruction to the employee to do a particular thing, so whenever the employee is in this waiting period, there always exists the possibility of being recalled to duty whatever the instructions he was given at the outset of that period.

The only other point I'd like to make is that I think our reading of the statute is buttressed by the other point at which time spent in deadhead transportation is used in the same section of the Hours of Service Act.

That is, the act provides that time spent in deadhead transportation to a duty assignment is considered time on duty, and I feel quite certain that the union would state that time spent in deadhead transportation to a duty assignment includes any waiting period between the time that the employee reports and the time that the deadhead vehicle is actually ready to go.

That's buttressed by the structure of the statute and by the legislative history, which the Senate report states that time spent in deadhead transportation to a duty assignment is to be calculated from the time an employee reports for duty, so this gives further confirmation of the fact that the waiting period is properly included within the phrase, time spent in deadhead transportation.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Stewart.
Mr. Johnson, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court:

Before the Ninth Circuit ruling, there was... the statutory scheme was administered in a very straightforward, simple manner, predictable and certainty for the railroad in how to schedule crews and operate their trains.

The very simple rule that the Hours of Service Act provided was that you could operate the crew up to 12 hours, but if you realized, if you saw that the train was not going to make its intended terminal, all you had to do to avoid a violation of the act was notify the crew to identify a place where they could pull over, park the train, and then they were relieved from all other duty.
At that point, all they had to do was wait for transportation to arrive, which typically also brought the relief crew as well.
The relief crew got on the train, took the train on to its terminal, then the expired or outlawed crew would be transported to its place of final release.
Now, one thing I'd like to make clear right here is--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What do you call them?
You call them an outlawed crew?
Is that the industry terminology?

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: --There's a lot of industry jargon, Your Honor, and the crew is outlawed at that point in time.
The crew sometimes sent out to pick it up was called the dog-catcher, to pick up the outlawed train.
[Laughter]

Now, one thing I'd like to point out here is a difference between us and the unions, one among many differences, is that they try and argue that under the statute the crew is on duty until it reaches its place of final release, which is the terminal that it didn't make, but that's not the way the statute works.

The language is quite clear that on duty runs from the time you report for duty until you're finally released from duty, and you're finally released from duty under the statute when the railroad dispatcher advises the crew you're relieved from duty, don't do anything else.
Now, I believe in response to a question from Justice Breyer was asked, are these crews paid while they're in limbo time, and the answer is yes, they are paid all throughout this time.
They're paid while they're waiting for deadhead transportation.
They're paid while they're in the deadhead transportation vehicle.
They're paid until they get to their final terminal.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: What about the period of time when the employee reports to go on duty, and is waiting for transportation to the duty station?

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: Well, they're paid at that point in time, too, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: For the waiting period?

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: Yes, and actually they're paid a little extra amount, because--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: And are they considered on duty during the waiting period?

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.

From the time they report to duty... I mean, typically there's a train... they try and schedule it so the train is there ready for them to get on board and go on, but if the train hasn't come in yet, that time period they're waiting to assume duty and that's counted as on-duty time.

But to come back to the point I was going to make about the pay, all that happens at the place of final release, they don't have any more duties because they've been relieved from duty on the train, they have no duties while they're waiting for deadhead transportation, they have no duties while they're in the taxicab or the van, or another train, perhaps, but they're being paid, and when they get to the place of final release, all that is, is they clock out.
That's all final release means.
When they get to their terminal, they clock out.
That stops the pay, and it starts their rest period, because the railroad has to know when the rest period begins so they can be called again.
Now, there aren't any abuses here.

I know the union attorney talks about abuses in the record, but there really is no record here other than what was put before the agency by the railroads, because the union did not put anything in the record other than the stuff they've attached to their briefs.

But even if there were abuses here, the abuses were whatever they were related to deadhead transportation, and they've all been addressed by the fact that waiting for deadhead transportation and the deadhead transportation itself is not counted towards the rest period, and therefore, when they get to the end, when they get to the place of final release, they get their full rest period.
Now, it's been very hard for the railroads to try and comply with this new interpretation, and that is why the railroads went to court.
It is impossible to always predict, now... before, you could simply predict that when the train would be outlawed, you could just tell the crew to stop.
You wouldn't violate the law.
The only variable you had to have was to pick a place where they could pull the train aside off the main line onto a siding.
Now, you have to try and predict not only where they're going to reach the 12-hour maximum, you have to also work in other variables.
You have to call transportation, try to get transportation to meet a place before the 12 hours... it just can't be done.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: What penalties are there for violating... I mean, I can imagine you might have a snowstorm or something, and you can just stop the train, but if that unforeseen delay causes your crew to be on duty longer than you had expected, what would the penalties be?

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: Well, the penalties, the minimum penalty to be imposed is $500 per violation.
The maximum penalty is $20,000 per violation.
The violation, each crew member is a violation, so if you have three members on the crew, that's three violations.
That would be three times whatever the amount is.
Now, the agency has discretion above $500 how much to impose.
Currently, what they've been imposing is $1,000 per violation, so each of these crews typically has a crew of two or three people, it's $2,000 or $3,000 per violation.
Now, the problem here is, it's impossible--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Of course, they might make an exception for snowstorms.

You know, even if we adopted the union's view of the matter, there... couldn't we count on the agency's discretion not to impose the penalty when indeed the reason the excessive time occurred was simply some unforeseen event such as a snowstorm?

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.
They have that... I think it's a matter of prosecutorial discretion, and also there's a specific exception in the statute for emergency situation acts of God.

But what's happening right now in the Ninth Circuit, because they still feel compelled to apply this interpretation of the Ninth Circuit, in the States within the Ninth Circuit, the railroads are continuing to be assessed violations for this waiting time.
Even though the waiting time periods are as little as 5 minutes, we're still being faced with penalties right now.
Now, I'd like to talk briefly about interim rest periods.

It's clear that interim means you're between points of duty, and all that Congress was trying to get at when they put interim... when they defined what interim periods of rest were in the statute is, the case law before 1969 was all over the place.
You know, some courts would say 2 hours works, some courts would say 3 hours works.
All Congress did was codified that it has to be at least 4 hours, and it has to be at a certain place where accomodations are available for rest.
Now--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: May I ask to whom the penalties are paid for violations?

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: --The penalties are paid to the United States Government.
I assume they go into the Treasury, Your Honor.

Now, the current interpretation that the union wants just makes no sense, because the crew has been relieve from all duties, has no duties, but yet they would have that crew continue to be counted as on duty even though they're not physically on the train, even though they have no further duties.
It just doesn't make any sense.
There's no safety problem here because the crew is not going to be allowed to operate a train again until after they've received their full rest period, and--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, of course, I mean, you know, an argument can be made for the other side.
The argument is... what is the rest period that's... what's the minimum rest period?

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: --The minimum rest period is 8 hours.
If they work right up to the maximum of 12 hours, it is 10 hours under the statute.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: Now, that rest period doesn't begin... what happens when they reach... you know, there's all this railroad industry jargon in the statute, but again, the place of final release simply means the building that they walk into when they clock out.
That means they're going to begin their rest period, and what they do then is, if they're... I believe one of the justices asked how many terminals they have.

They have the home terminal... the home terminal, of course, they live at their home, but when they get to their away-from-home terminal, the railroad has made arrangements... it's in the collective bargaining agreement.
This is all treated in the collective bargaining agreements... has made arrangements for a hotel to go to and stuff, and that's where they get their rest.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Okay, but doesn't this scheme of the statute show that Congress thought that an 8-hour rest period is needed for a... what, 10-hour normal work period?

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But a 10-hour rest period is needed for a 12-hour work period, is that right?

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So the law... you can't say there's just an absolute rest period which is going to be a balm for all ills, no matter how long you've been on... you know, working before then, and what the union is saying is look, realistically, traveling, deadheading back is... it takes it out of you, and if I should get 10 hours' rest for 12 hours' duty, I should also get 10 hours' rest for 10 hours of duty plus 2 hours of deadheading back, including the waiting time for the deadheading.
I don't know that that's an unreasonable argument.

I mean, the minimum time is a minimum time that has been calculated on the basis of what the maximum duty time was, and if that duty time is stretched out, maybe... you know, maybe the minimum time should be more.

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: Your Honor, they have a way to get that, and the way they get that is expressly addressed in the statute, and that is through collective bargaining.

Congress specifically says in section 2107 of the Hours of Service Act that these are minimums, and nothing is to stop the parties from sitting down and collectively bargaining longer rest periods, and--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: This is a safety issue, they say, and Congress... you know, Congress was concerned with safety.

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: --That's true, Your Honor, and Congress, though, has made the judgment that safety is satisfied here.

If we limit the crews to 12 hours on duty, if we make transportation time limbo time, and if we mandate a minimum rest period of 8 hours, Congress has made a judgment that that satisfies the safety concern, and if the parties want to go beyond that minimum they can and, in fact, they have, and some collective bargaining agreements provide that the minimum rest period is, in all instances is 10 hours rather than 8 hours.
And the safety issue, though, here that the unions are complaining about is not the safety issue of waiting time, it's not the safety issue of how long the day is.

You read their brief, and over and over and over again, the safety problem they're worried about is fatigue from irregular work hours, upsetting Circadian rhythms because crews are being called at all hours of the day and night to man trains, and that's true.
That's the way the railroad business works.

But that is not a safety issue that's addressed by this statute, because even if you counted waiting time as limbo time, that doesn't affect the fact that the crew, when it gets back and after it's had its rest, could be called again at any hour of the day or night to man that train.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Indeed, it's purely fortuitous whether it helps that problem or hurts that problem.
It could help it.

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor, and again, the parties are meeting together in task force to address the safety issues that may result from these irregular work schedules, and Congress last year did add an amendment to the Hours of Service Act that encouraged the parties to work together to develop a solution, if there is a problem here, on irregular work hours.

But there's not a safety problem here with treating waiting time as limbo time, and the Government made a reasonable choice in a somewhat ambiguous term whether to treat it... that's one difference we have with the Government.
We believe there are only two options on how to treat this waiting time.
It can either be treated as off-duty time or limbo time, and the Government made a reasonable choice to treat it as limbo time.
That's the way this statute has operated for more than 20 years, and we believe that's the correct application of the statute.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask one very important question?
The term dog-catcher refers to the crew that picks up the outlawed crew, or to the crew that substitutes for it?

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: That picks... that refers to the crew that comes out from the terminal to pick up the train that got outlawed because it fell short of its final destination because the first crew outlawed--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So they're the substitute crew.

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: --They're the substitute crew, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: ronald_m_johnson
turn.label: Mr. Ronald M. Johnson
turn.text: I thank the Court.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Johnson.
The case is submitted.
